section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge; Print Concepts

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the alphabet, recite a poem about families, and introduce vocabulary word (empty).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, Who goes to Mouse’s family reunion?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Display appropriate book handling behaviors.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Show understanding of text read aloud.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify the Alphabet Letter Card that shows the first letter of their name.
Invite children to then decorate the first letter of their name.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Do you see a family in your story? Who is in that family?
What family member can you pretend to be?
Can you show with cubes how many people are in your family?
Draw a picture of a family. Can you tell me who each person is?
What materials would you use to make an elephant puppet?
Can you find the letter that begins your name? Do you know any other letters in your name?
What blocks can you use to make a house for a family?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Try to Resolve Conflicts Mind Builder, and introduce related vocabulary (warm welcome, decided).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Little Elliot, Big Family.
Read closely and notice when a conflict is being resolved.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Display appropriate book handling behaviors.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Use and identify different digital tools.

small-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Ball, Basket, Plastic Hoop, Bean Bag

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Pair children for three activities.
Encourage partners to take turns using the sentence, “Please, may I have a turn?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose a book about a family. Who is in the family?
With a partner, can you take turns acting out your family’s favorite activity?
Take a handful of cubes. Pretend they are presents for Elliot. How many are there?
Can you draw a picture of Mouse and Elliot? Can you label it?
How can you make something for Elliot to give to Mouse?
Look at the Alphabet Cards. What letter does your name begin with? Can you make that letter in shaving cream?
Build Mouse and Elliot’s tall apartment building. How tall is it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Little Elliot, Big Family by Mike Curato. Copyright © 2015 by Mike Curato. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Henry Holt and Company, LLC. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: basket (gowithstock), juggling balls (Bjoern Wylezich), sport balls (New Africa).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension strategy, engage children with a movement activity, and introduce vocabulary (wondered).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Little Elliot, Big Family and asking, Who does Elliot see on his walk?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Display appropriate book handling behaviors.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to make Elliot a part of their own family by drawing a picture of their family enjoying an activity and including Elliot in the fun.
Ask children to share their pictures and guide them to see that families can be different sizes.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose a book to listen to. Why did you choose that book?
Play Going for a Ride with classmates. Can you take turns “driving” the family to different places around town?
Can you use counting cubes to show how many people are in your family?
Draw a picture of someone in your family. Can you write why they are special?
How can you make a surprise for someone in your family? Why did you choose those materials?
Can you find a Magnetic Letter to match the Alphabet Cards A, B, and C?
How can you make a theater out of blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Little Elliot, Big Family by Mike Curato. Copyright © 2015 by Mike Curato. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Henry Holt and Company, LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: My Family and Me
Big Book: Little Elliot, Big Family

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about families, recite a poem, and introduce vocabulary (grandparents, grandchild).
Begin Story Time by connecting Little Elliot, Big Family and My Family and Me.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question, What makes a family?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Display appropriate book handling behaviors.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Encourage children to make portraits of Mouse’s family members.
Talk about family activities and which family members participate in them.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Compare two books about families. What is the same about both families? Different?
What clothes do you think are good to put on if you are pretending to be a grown-up?
Use plastic people or dolls to create a family. Can you count how many members are in this family?
Can you draw your family on an adventure? Draw a picture and write about it!
How can you make a pretend family with the different objects?
Can you find Magnetic Letters that have parts that are like circles?
Do you think you can build a car for a family? Will it be big or small?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Little Elliot, Big Family by Mike Curato. Copyright © 2015 by Mike Curato. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Henry Holt and Company, LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children sing and act out what they like to do with their families and to introduce vocabulary (missed you).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What do we do with our families?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Display appropriate book handling behaviors.
Identify that there is meaning in text.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Who can be the people in a family?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Share your book of feelings. Tell your partner one thing you like about their book.
Can you pretend you are baking muffins for someone in your family?
What feeling does each person have? Can you sort the cards by feeling?
Make a card for your family. Can you write “I love you”?
Mouse is Elliot’s best friend. Can you draw your best friend?
Imagine you are a teacher. Can you sing “The Alphabet Song” to your class of stuffed animals?
Imagine the play people are a family. How do they act and talk?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Little Elliot, Big Family by Mike Curato. Copyright © 2015 by Mike Curato. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Henry Holt and Company, LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use, operate, and name a variety of digital tools.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole- /small-group writing activities.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Retell or re-enact a story after it is read aloud.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Recognize that text has meaning.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
